This corner bracket replaces the broken or lost corner brackets used on the "Bessey" web clamp. It is a one piece clamp unlike the original part which is made up of several parts. A simple, yet effective part for all woodwork clamping of various box construction.

The corner clamp is printed using a medium setting with 10% infil. It can be printed either flat on its side or on the points of the clamp opening. Both methods of printing will require supports to complete the build successfully. Pictures show the MakerBot support  when printed on its side. After the build you need to carefully remove the support to reveal the finished clamp. Be careful not to break the two web locating lugs on the outside circumference of the clamp. A little hand sanding of the part maybe required to complete the part.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2ExwpBKcyOk

The universal vertex module (UVM) allows to build complex structures by assembling them together. The vertices are assembled using cable ties at 90 degree angles. The connecting material between the vertices can be anything: wood, PVC piping, anything lying around... This part is fully documented on its own GitHub repository A parametric version is available to customise the UVM

title: CTC Switch Box for KCD11 switches

description.text:
I needed a switch box to control an extruder fan and LED lighting. I had at home a bunch of small KCD11 SPST switches KCD11 (http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-100pcs-LOT-250VAC-3A-Connectors-3-Pin-ON-OFF-Rocker-Switch-KCD11-8-5/1993568872.html), and found the nice designed box ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1080129 ) by softwarebaer. Unfortunately, the switches he used for his box are larger than the ones I have, so I redesigned a new box... This box is to be mounted in the lower right corner of a CTC Bizer (Dual) made of 5,5mm wooden panels. Any other printer brand that uses the same kind of construction could also be equipped with this box. You can Tinker with the box to modify it to your needs...
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hfamkEVPUtx

The 'Mummy'
a Mummy head to print to scare
Designed in Sculptris and should print easily

"Jemari" (fingers) is a 3D printed hand. The aim of this project is to make robotic prosthetic hands more accessible to amputees. Leading prosthetics can cost up to $100,000. By using emerging technologies like 3D printing, we can cut that down to under $500.
Jemari is an open-source project which means that all of the know-how you need to create one of these magnificent devices will be available here and/or on my website. What’s more, anyone can improve and customise the designs themselves and then upload them for everyone to share.
Complete instructions (coming soon) to make can be found in ---> www.paksudelta.com
Facebook: Sujana Rejab
All comments and suggestions are most welcome to improve Jemari.
Thanks to Thingiverse for providing this platform for me and everyone sharing.

author: gmunday1976

title: Small hex screwdriver handle with magnet

description.text:
I wanted the ability to change bits frequently without eventual loosening due to wear on the plastic - a magnet seemed like the best approach.  I have added a cavity that allows for a circular neodymium magnet (5mm diameter, 3mm thickness) to be included, secured with a drop of superglue.
I have included the OpenScad file I wrote to add the cavity to 4volt's original .stl - it is fairly simple to change the values to accommodate different sized circular magnets.  All the script does is remove a cylinder from the original design, so you will need to download 4volt's original to the same location as the OpenScad file for it to work.  Details of this are included as comments in the file.
To those unfamiliar with OpenScad, let me know in the comments if you need an .stl file for a particular magnet and I will add them when I get a chance.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Securing the magnet I stuck the magnet to an Allen key (use anything magnetic, a drill bit works well too), added a drop of superglue to the face of the magnet and used the key to press it into the hole.

title: Baby Gate Support - No Screws Needed

description.text: Continuing with the theme from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:100772 of not being able to find pieces of our baby gates... This support replaces a cup shaped piece that is supposed to be screwed to the wall for a Regalo Baby Step baby gate. We never installed those pieces for our first child as she wasn't really the type to explore destructively. Second one seems to take after me a little bit more in that respect, so the reinforcement piece is needed. If you happen to have the exact same gate mounted to the exact same opening, you might be able to use this stl file. I think the concept is good though, so its worth taking a few minutes to CAD up for your gate (or rescale the stl). edit: Check out this great customizer version by cfinke http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1383808

This is designed to be printed on a 0.4mm nozzle with 1 extra shell.  The thin spot that the gate presses against is 1.6mm wide.  
I printed it with 20% infill and 1mm top and bottom in PLA.

author: bisens

description.text:
I liked the coffee sleeves that Sethmoser (thing:99020) made but it needed something else...like...GEARS!! This coffee sleeve has a gear mechanism that rotates. Play with your coffee!
I designed this in Rhino as a fun sunday project and is my very first attempt at making something with gears.
Here is a video of it in action!!
http://youtu.be/O1MScAzDgrw
Enjoy!!

Print each piece in your own colour combo!
As with most of my designs, it prints without support and raft. I have also posted a set of four gears for those with a TOM or other small bed printer, just print it twice. All components will fit comfortably on a 100mm plate. You might squeeeze it on a Cupcake as it is 85 mm. I think that would be awesome!
I printed the one you see here on my Replicator1 using firmware V7.3, Makerware 2.2.0 at standard settings 10% infill, 2 extra shells. Assemble it by putting the pins through the gears then in the sleeve. You may have to clean out the holes in the sleeve but only a little. The pins are capable of a very nice press fit for no glue needed!
Show off your kick ass, caffeinated, java, cup of deliciousness now with Gears! mmm cofffeeeeee!

Hello, my friend Javier Román and me, Alexander Gil, want to present our project: Antdroid is an hexapod fully open source, low cost and 3D printed. It's based in Arduino Mega and Raspberry Pi, its mainly features are:
  • Parametric and modular design.
  • Inverse kinematic implementation.
  • 18 DOF.
  • Camera streaming.
  • Gamepad control (ps3 sixaxis) and keyboard control.
  • WiFi and BT(optional).
  • Automatic control from camera. (Antdroid loves green balls and hates red ones)
    • Vitamins list:https://github.com/antdroid-hexapod/antdroid/wiki/Assembly-guide#vitamins The robot can work only with the Arduino and been controlled by a bluetooth from firmware( this is not implement but could be easily added ). Instead, we implemented a more advanced control in a Raspberry Pi with ROS. That allows us to have an intelligent robot instead of a radio control simply robot. Video working: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLFBM_ZKkZxwaD9ibE9dxWIhVkLHhmYMVi Website: http://antdroid.grigri.cloud/ Wiki: https://github.com/antdroid-hexapod/antdroid/wiki EDIT: Update to first finish version v1.0 Assembly:
    Body: https://youtu.be/AJv0l73hyFw
    Leg: https://youtu.be/hS5I1h_2Tz0
    Servo: https://youtu.be/zvCjepw4Xqk Project: https://youtu.be/vFuBMoKWzhE
    Intro: https://youtu.be/RHwGIMdeDdw
    Camera control: https://youtu.be/QbeVCcTpIk0

comments.author: pando85

comments.text: Is there any reason not to use MG995 servos, at least for some servos (like the 'hips')?  Or must they all be MG996Rs?  My understanding is that the MG996R is an upgraded version of the MG995.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Yes, you can use another less powered servor for the hips. We choose MG996R for all becouse it was simpler in the design and easier to buy in big quantity. And the cost of MG996R is arround 4 euros...
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Thanks.  I ended up using the MG996Rs (they finally arrived) anyway.  In the drawings for Coxa, I can tell you that those parts have holes that are dangerously close to the edge of the material and can't take a whole lot of lateral strain.  I had to repair 2 of them (ABS or PLA) using Squadron putty.  If at all possible, I would make the holes at least 2 hole diameters away from the edge.  I realize that would enlarge Coxa by 6mm in 2 axes but the ability to drive a screw in there and have it stay in there would be improved.  I am looking at thermoplastic inserts in some places as well.  One more question.  The documentation specifies the centered location of servos on the body.  So let's say the servo turns through 180 degrees (0 to 180).  Then I am turning the servo to 90 degrees and mounting on the body so that, say, the left front leg is 45 degrees to the left center leg.  The left center leg is 90 degrees to the body with the servo centered.  Is this correct?  I ask because it seems I am centering by hand.  Is  it ok to do this because my hand positioning will be largely approximate.
comments.author: pando85

comments.text: About the holes: in our prototypes its looks a little bit ugly but it doesn't cause any mechanical problem. It's a little more difficult to thread screws in but nothing important.

description.text: Kiss

title: One Servo Walker - Single Servo Robot

description.text:
This project is my attempt at creating a walking, steerable robot using a single servo. And... it works!! :D MONTAGE!! - 'cause even Rocky had a montage! :P
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ThbiHAMHhRc Video showing how he turns and walks
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qRtXrHbw63I His gait is a bit rough at the moment, so I need to do more work on the software, but he is able to walk and turn, so I'm going to keep working on this. :D The design of this robot was based on and inspired by the one servo walking robot created by user "ercost60" on YouTube. See a video of his robot here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4CaAq6gQbLY (In some ways, the way this robot works is kind of like a motorised version of my Wobbly automaton!) I'm still tinkering with my build. I want to add sensors to this robot, and perhaps also add bluetooth so that I can control him with an app (like in some of my other projects). To build this, you need to print:
1 x FrontBody
2 x FrontLeg
1 x FrontGuard
1 x RearBody I used an Arduino Micro as the controller, but you can use any controller. It is a single servo, so you may want to try controlling it without a microcontroller! :D You can see details on how to assemble this here: http://www.cevinius.com/2015/10/19/one-servo-walker-update/

Light Extrusions is a photography experiment that captures light trails generated from a 3d model. Only instead of printing with plastic filament, it uses light from an LED. A camera captures the light using long exposure photography. For more information about the Light Extrusion project, head over to http://www.uncontrol.com/posts/light-extrusion-experiment/

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

1 mm layer height, 1 shell

Infill:

0%

Notes: Size the 3d model to under 80mm x 80mm x 80mm.
Position the 3d model in front, left of the build plate, floating in mid air. Makerbot desktop will try to place the object on the build plate. Add a small object on the build plate to bypass this issue. outline speed 150
travel speed 150 *1 mm layer height is outside the range of Makerbot desktop. You will need to edit the profiles using an external editor.

Instructions Below are instructions on how to make your very own Light Extruder. Disclaimer I do not claim any responsibility for any damages made to your extruder or printer. Build at your own risk. Parts List
  • Rotary Encoder - 200 P/R (Quadrature)
  • 1/16" (1.6mm) Clear 83A O-ring Belt, Cut-Length 6Round band
  • Arduino
  • Transistors, wires, LEDs, toggle buttons, breadboard, jumpers, shrink wrap, etc.
  • large cardboard box
  • fiber optic band.
    • Step 1 The Encoder + Arduino
  • Connect the encoder directly to the Arduino using the above diagram. There’s an extra wire for ground, I ignored it, it’s up to you.
  • Use test code from the rotary encoder's comments section to see if you’re reading the values in. Different Arduinos require different pin numbers so update yours accordingly. If your serial monitor it outputting numbers then it's working.
  • Wire up the rest of the parts as shown.
  • Use the new code with added toggle switch.
  • Use an Arduino and breadboard mount to keep everything tidy.
    • Step 2 Preparing the Extruder.
  • Print out the extruder mount, the cog wheel and a mount for the arduino. first. Use dark filament if possible.
  • Warning, going past this point will probably void your warranty. I take no responsibility if you break it.
  • Remove the extruder from the Printer. If it’s heated, wait for it to cool. clip off excess filament.
  • Gently remove the guard near the tip of the extruder.
  • Gently remove the yellow void sticker.
  • Gently pry the extruder open without breaking the connector pins. use this video for help. If you break it the pins, it can still be be salvageable by tapping it shut with gaffer tape.
  • When you open it, everything will fly out. That's expected.
    • castle nut + 2 bearings
    • black extruder spring mechanism
    • small black filament bridge thing
    • excess filament
  • Set aside the parts above.
  • At the top near the wheel thing there is a small green circuit board held in place with a phillips head. That is the filament detection board. We won’t need it so unscrew, lift up and set aside along with the connected black piece.
  • What you should see now are four pins sticking up. You will need to connect only 1 jumper across the top 2 pins.
  • The jumper I used was loose so I ended up removing the black part completely and soldered the jumper directly to the pins.
  • Test the round band by only putting back the castle nut and bearings with this photo.
  • The band will be rubbing next to the wheel opening so use a round filing chisel to file down the extruder casing.
  • Put the close the extruder casing without the spring mechanism and small black filament bridge thing.
  • To test, pull the band and the castle nut should freely rotate. there should be no friction at all.
  • Add the guard back for stability.
  • Attach the mount to the extruder. I use gaffer tape to fill any extra space between the extruder and mount for a snug fit. Make sure you constantly attach/reattach the extruder to the printer to prevent any alignment issues with the gaffer tape.
    • Step 3 Light Source
  • Cut extra wires to make sure the LED is 4-5 inches longer than the encoder wire.
  • Prick a small hole on some gaffer tape and wrap the led so no light leaks happen.
  • For a tighter beam…
    1. Bend fiber optic wire at a right angle.
    2. Take lighter to the tip of the fiber optic wire to make a larger surface area Crazy glue fiber optic wire directly to LED
    3. Once dried, take a strip of gaffer tape and carefully wrap the led and fiber optic wire. try to make sure there are no air pockets
    4. Use a scissor to cut off excess tape and fiber wire.
    5. A tiny sliver of fiber optic wire should be peaking out from the edge of the gaffer tape.
    • Step 4 Assembling the Light Extruder
  • The encoder should have a black cover around the rotating bit, remove with a hex wrench and add the cog. (the cog should only fit one way).
  • Slide the encoder into the mount. Use gaffer tape around the encoder for a snug fit.
  • Attach the round belt to the cog and the encode should be ready.
  • Congratulations your Light Extruder is complete!
    • Step 5 Prepping the Extruder.
  • Using a large box (preferably the one that came with the printer), place the box sideways (handles up) and fit the printer in the box. Open up the “bottom” of the box so you can reach the back of the printer to connect any cables. seal up with tape.
  • Attach the light extruder to the printer and hang the arduino mount to the top using paper clips punched through the box. I positioned the arduino to the left side of the box to ensure there’s enough tension on the wire.
  • Make sure you use extra paper clips to hang the connecting wire above the extruder because it will sometimes get caught between the extruder and the machine.
    • Printing and Capturing
  • Use the print settings listed above, Some settings are outside of what Makerbot Desktop recommends. You will need to edit the profiles using an external editor.
  • Position the camera at the back right of the build plate. Anywhere else may interfere with the printing process and may damage your camera
  • Cameras will have different options. I manually focused the camera approximately where I think the model would be, used the lowest exposure setting possible and set up Bulb Mode with a remote control to handle the long exposure.
  • When you send an file to print, start the camera after it lays down the long strip of filament (or when the build plate moves up for in the air prints)
  • Use Makerbot Desktop to monitor the print
  • Unlock the remote after the model has finished printing
    • Trial and Error Getting my first capture took tons of trial and error. I originally used an iPhone with apps like Slow Shutter Cam and NightCap Pro to handle the long exposure capture but the results were too inconsistent. Your milage may vary. When you finally get a print you like, make sure you post a made one so everyone can see your results. Happy light extruding!

title: SHP9500 Replacement Earpad Clip - HM5 Etc.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: If you have ever had to (or thought of) replacing the pads on the Philips SHP9500 headphones (which are not "user replaceable"), these are for you.  If you have ever seen it, you know the stock ear pad retention ring is very large, and is too large to fit most replacement pads [some can stretch to fit, but you risk tearing].  This simple ring snaps into place of the stock retention ring and allows you to mount smaller replacement pads - such as the Brainwavz HM5 pads [which I like].  While these rings look flimsy, I had no issues when printing them out of standard [hard] PLA.  They are just flexible enough to fit over the clips, while being strong enough to stay on in day to day use.  Initially, I tried making a design that would have slots built in for the clips, but then I realized the clips are simply the perimeter of a circle - so I simple cut out the exact right size of that circle.  Also, the clips taper near the top [as designed] and should be mounted with the top facing "down" [towards the driver].  Note: I am not going to tell you how to remove the stock pads for liability reasons - just google how to do it and you should be able to find pictures and / or videos.

description.text:
• What is it exactly ?
    • This is the first version of my personal study project: a close to entirely 3D printed mechanical hand that is completly functional.
  • Why is this here ?
    • This is the first version of my personal study project. I'm happy to share this with the community beacause I'm searching for improvement. Please feel free to download, test and change it or tell me if you've got suggestion for the design ;-)
  • How does it work ?
    • The hand is equiped with five mobile fingers individuably actionable trough a integrated string system. By pulling each string you can action every finger individually, if you release the rope, an elastic will snap the finger back in the original position. (Whatch the video on the bottom of this page)
  • How do I build it ?
    • Instructions are down below ;-) (updated)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Highest possible

Infill:

100%

Building instructions Material needed:
  • Scissors
  • Pliers
  • Awl
  • 1mm Fishing rope (Nylon thread)
  • 0.8 mm Elastic rope
  • 8x nails 1.8 mm (0.07 inch)
  • Toothpicks
  • Sandpaper
  • Patafix or glue
    • To print:
  • 1x Palm
  • 1x tumb
  • 4x finger
  • 5x Phalanx
  • (optional) 1x handle
    • To prepare:

  • Make sure all parts and holes were printed well and are unubstructed. If not, use the awl to free them or make them large enough. Also test the fingers and the phalanxes, their hinges should freely move and have minimal friction, therfore and all other imperfection use the sandpaper.

  • Take 6 nails and put them through the finger, they will serve as hinges. Once in, your will need to cut of the exeeding part off the nail with the pliers.

  • Take the 2 remaining nails and cut them off to fit exactly through half on each side of the hinge connecting the palm to the phalanxes.

  • Prepare 5x 30 cm (1 foot) long pieces of nylon thread, do the same with the elastic one.

  • Cut the tips off 5 toothpicks (1 cm from the end)
    • Assembly:

  • Make a big knot on one end of each thread (nylon AND elastic)

  • Pass the nylon string through the finger's top hole (the one facing the palm) and continue through the phalanx and the palm. Check that your knot is holding in the finger, the other end should be comming out on the back of the hand.

  • Repeat the same process with the elastic band, except passing through the bottom hole, the rope should come out the bottom of the palm.

  • Take the patafix under the nail's head and put those hinges to connect the phalanxes to the fingers and to the palm.

  • Stretch the elastic ropes until the hand stays open by itself but is still easy to close. Hold them in place by fixing them with the toothpicks and the bottom of the palm.
    • (Optional)

  • Pass the ends of the nylon threads through the handle's holes. Check that all fingers close at the same time, mark their position. Now make another pair of knots.

  • You can finalise the hand by adding some felt on the surfaces (exemple on the picture) for better grip.
    • Congratulations ! Your hand is now completed ! (^-^)/ Enjoy !

[edit] Now with leg3.stl, reinforced further at the screw holes.

The MFJ-1899T Portable Multi Band Antenna is hard to keep in one place. It was designed for “walkabout” use. I tried propping it on chairs, taping it to the railing and even putting it into an empty box to keep it upright. If only I had a suction cup mount, I could place that portable antenna on any smooth surface. Use an inexpensive dual suction cup Bath Safety Grip Handle sold by Harbor Freight (item#96086). This thing is meant to hold a person from slipping in the shower, and it is about the stickiest suction cup I have ever found. Print using standard resolution and a 10% infill, 2 shells, and 0.20 mm layer height. These are standard print settings. I am pretty sure if you are ‘close enough’ the design will work for you too. It is a symmetrical part so you will need four pieces to make the mount shown. Each part piece took about 50 minutes to print on my printer. It is made out of PLA plastic filament material.
Assemble using Hillman part number 881526 14-20x2 Nylon machine screws, and Hillman 881556 ¼-20 Nylon wing nuts that you can obtain at any Lowes store. You will need 6 of each. References:
[1] http://www.harborfreight.com/household/assisted-living/bath-safety-grip-handle-96086.html
[2] http://www.lowes.com/pd_139010-37672-881526_0__?Ntt=881526&UserSearch=881526&productId=3050761&rpp=32
[3] http://www.lowes.com/pd_138998-37672-881556_0__?Ntt=881556&UserSearch=881556&productId=3013046&rpp=32

I have students who are working on a design and would love to tell them we have a solution so they could actually print it!
comments.author: MsBurton

comments.text: it was not 0.5 mm it was just 0.2 mm even a little bit less then that but I think you just will need to play with this value a little bit ;)
comments.author: MsBurton

comments.text:
I just used blender because I think it is a great program and it is free
I just designed the case as a complete part which would be the one in the description (I filled the hole where you could read the Sony). The next thing I did was to design just a line of the jigsaw and solidified it to 0.5 mm (with a modifier in blender). After that I put the 2 pieces (jigsaw and case) in 1 file and placed the jigsaw where I wanted the case to be separated and used the boolean modifier (difference to split it apart) by pressing "L" (just the letter on the keyboard) you select all linked faces (/edges/vertices) in a model and by pressing "P" you can chose to separate the mesh parts.

This is RepRapPro extruder drive redesigned to use NEMA14 stepper motor. Original version of mini extruder designed to use NEMA17 motor. It is not suitable for me because other motors on my Huxley are NEMA14.
Old version of RepRapPro extruder for Huxley based on NEMA14 stepper to but has another gear ratio. This design tested for 1/2 of year on my printer. NEMA14 stepper motor with 14 N/cm holding torque is suitable to operate in this extruder design.

• Extruder body size changed to fit NEMA14 stepper motor
  • Add slot to mount nut
  • Tension nut slot changed
  • Spacer source code totally rewrite
  • New designed filament drive bracket. Provided as separate customizable thing
    • Tongue slot looks strange but operate properly for 6 months. Tongue fix the Bowden tube with enough strange and never unfix.
    All changes commented in source files.

description.header: Original printed parts used (not changed, provided for convenient):
description.text:
• Small gear
  • Large gear
  • Tongue

• Hobbed insert from Geared Extruder Hardware Upgrade Kit or Hobbed insert
  • 623 bearing X 3
  • M3x25 hex head screw (as shaft for large gear)
  • M3x16 X 4 (motor mount)
  • M3x12 (tension bearing shaft)
  • M3x25+ (tension tuning screws)
  • M3x20, M3x25 and two M3 nuts (extruder mount)

Spacer thickness depends on stepper motor shaft length. For motor SY35ST36-1004A with 21 mm shaft I use 2 mm spacer. For motor 14HS16-1004S with 24 mm shaft - 4 mm spacer. Spacer can't be less than 2 mm. Stepper motor with less then 21 mm shaft not suitable. Shaft length measured from main body of motor.
The same as original

I am very grateful RepRapPro for his Huxley design. I made my 3d printer based on this design and using many of their parts. I use this printer with great pleasure for several years. All parts of this thing open source or standard except Geared Extruder Hardware Upgrade Kit. RepRapPro doesn't publish design files of this part. I think it was made by mistake... Now days RepRapPro stop selling separate parts and sell only "parts kits". I understand business is business but it's sad.

description.text: this is my 2nd bio ball
red bio ball

This is a rainbow trout based on a 3D model in the Toucan Virtual Museum (http://www.toucan.co.jp/3DCGE.html) and altered using Netfabb and Blender to be more printable, along with a tutorial (below) on how to use these tools to fix some common issues. 3D Fish printing challenge: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:95601

This tutorial covers how to fix bad geometry to produce printable STL files using netfabb Studio and Blender. In addition to netfabb's STL repair we will explore Blender's geometry extrusion and boolean operations, two very powerful tools that make 3D work a lot easier. One of the many awesome things about 3D printing is it gives us the ability to create real-life models of exotic animals that could otherwise only be experienced through books and video. The Toucan Museum (http://www.toucan.co.jp/3DCGE.html) offers some very nice models of fish, plants and insects, but becuase they were designed for 3D rendering rather than 3D printing they have some issues that we will need to address in order to produce a viable physical object. Most of them have geometry holes because the gills aren't connected to the rest of the body. Also, the fins are extremely thin and far too fragile to print if the slicing software even picks up on them at all. We need to fix both of these in order to get a printable model.
  • Open Blender and import the desired 3DS file. For this example I used Toucan's rainbow trout (nizimasu) model.
  • Note all the black lines that aren't part of the geometry. Those are an artifact of the 3ds file and I want to get rid of them. Select all of the geometry parts of the fish.
  • Object>Join (ctrl+J) to join them as a single polygon group.
  • Delete all the stuff except for this polygon group, so just the fish remains. I did it by moving the fish out of the way, followed by a control-drag select and delete and then moving the fish back to the origin.
  • Press shift+D and then Enter to duplicate the mesh in place. Name one of them Fish and one of them Fins.
  • In the Fish mesh, delete the eyes and fins. In the Fins mesh, delete the fish body.
  • Move Fish out of the way, then select Fins and enter edit mode. Our model's fins are actually two planes instead of a single convex polygon and we want to get rid of one of the planes so we don't have orphan geometry. Select and remove one of each of the pairs of planes (easiest is probably to select a vertex on each fin and then Select>Linked and delete).
    • These fins are razor-thin and won't print unless we make them thicker. Luckily for us Blender can do this in a single operation.

  • For each fin, select a vertex, then select linked verticies, and (E)xtrude. Type in the number 0.0015 or similar small number. What this does is extrude the selected geometry (a plane) along the normal of that plane by 0.0015 units, turning our plane of zero thickness into a flat polygon of 0.0015 thickness. By extruding along the normal rather than along an axis we keep the right shape even if the polygon isn't axis-aligned such as the bottom fins.

  • The fish will look funny if the vertical fins aren't lined up right and they are currently a little bit off to the side. Select the vertical fins and (G))rab, Y +/- 0.00075 (depending on which of the planes you deleted). This will shift them over by half the extrusion width so they're centered.
    • We now have two parts of our fish, the fish body and the fins. We could combine them with the Join operation but this can cause some slicing problems due to internal geometry. Instead let's turn them into a single solid mesh with a boolean union.
  • Select the Fish object and move it back to the origin at 0,0,0. The Transform pane makes this much easier. In the right-hand Object Modifiers pane, select Add Modifier>Boolean. In the modier pane, set the Operation as Union and the Object as Fins. Then select Apply.
    • We now have a solid mesh of our fish body as well as the fins. We are ready to export, though we may want to scale it up first.

  • (optional) (S)cale up by some value because this mesh is rather small. I scaled it by a factor of 15 to get a 6 unit long model.

  • You may have some duplicate verticies. In Edit mode select all verticies, and Mesh>Vertices>Remove Doubles.

  • File>Export>STL. Give it a name and you've got an STL. Close Blender, we are done here.
    • We now have an STL but it has holes. We still need to fix it with netfabb.

  • Open netfabb Studio and import our newly created STL.

  • Select Extras>Repair Part.

  • Select Automatic Repair, Execute, and Apply Repair.

  • Select Part>Export Part>as STL. Give it a name and export.
    • At this point we have a perfectly fine fish that should print without issue. However, if you want to go an extra step and can print using soluble support, let's adjust our mesh so that it fits on a display stand. This might sound like it's going to be a lot of work but it's actually very simple with another Boolean operation in Blender.

  • Open Blender and import our fixed STL.

  • Create or import a stand such as the one included in my upload.

  • We are going to use the stand to punch a hole in our fish. Scale it up by a very small amount, like 1.008. Note that you might have to print the base at a slightly different scale to get it to fit but it's going to be a much faster and easier print than our fish.

  • Move the base so that it sticks into the fish around a quarter inch near the center of mass.

  • Select the fish, and in the Object Modifiers pane select Add Modifiers>Boolean. In the modifier pane, set the Operation as Difference and the Object as our base. Click Apply.

  • Export the STL.
    • Now we have our finished fish and it even fits on a stand, no drilling required! Note that printers can be a bit finicky with model dimensions so for a really good fit you might need to adjust the stand slightly, but it's a lot quicker and easier to print than the fish. I have also included a version that has some minor reinforcement around the bottom fins which was accomplished using another boolean operation.

description.text:
This is my 4s6p battery pack built with 18650 cells. I've added two balancing leads, one male and one female, along with 4 terminals to make it easy to connect these packs together in parallel. When connecting both + and - and the balancing leads, the packs can even be charged in parallel without using a balancing board. To complete this battery you'll need:
  • single-strand copper wire
  • 4 4mm banana plug terminals
  • 1 4s balancing lead extension cable
  • 24 18650 cells
  • basic soldering equipment
    • https://youtu.be/878PhtWXNY4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

As fine as possible of course!

Infill:

I used 30%

Notes: When printing this, it's probably a good idea to scale it up a bit in x and y dimensions. I scaled it up 2% to get the battery cells to fit. This was cells I had removed the insulation from as well.

description.text: Way back in 2007, I made a little paper chap I called Heed the Box. title: Triangular Based Pyramid Eppendorf Holder (58 holders)

description.text:
This is an Eppendorf holder with 58 usable holes (86 total).
I designed it for 1.5ml eppendorfs but if you find other uses for it then go ahead :)
The reason why it has 86 in total is that I made the holder a perfect triangular based pyramid, so which ever face you place it on you'll always have 58 holes to use. I consider this a space efficient holder for the number you can fit on it, however I don't know whether it can't be printed on certain printers as its 13.4 cm's high and 15.1 cm's wide.
I know it can print on a Makerbot Replicator 2 plate bed. From a resolution standpoint I have no idea! There are small parts in the holes which may interfere with each other but if someone could be really helpful and tell me to help others it will be appreciated! This is pretty big so might need quite a bit of plastic. Please comment any problems you may have or even some improvements you might think of. Thanks :D

Update | Mini Version I decided to create a smaller version of the original..well one with less holes as I'm sure a few people wont be using that many eppendorfs at once, plus it should make it more likely to print on smaller printers. This version has 34 usable holes and 52 total. Update | Micro Version Just for the fun of it I made a Micro Version.
Not sure how balanced this will be with eppondorfs on it. This version has 14 usable holes and 24 total.

author: TBNRStarn

title: Stepper driver trimpot aligner / screwdriver tool

description.text: If you want to align / set your stepper motor drivers, you need a (non-conductive) plastic or ceramic tool which is cheap but difficult to find. Fear not, because this is a working substitute made with PLA, with phillips and slotted version and screwdriver adapter.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

15%

Notes: o start, this is a very difficult print. It might not work well in every printer. Please try to print the shapes exactly as they are given, otherwise it will not work. No support. You can use brim, it worked for me, but you can also print without it. You HAVE to use PLA or another rigid material, because ABS is too flexible for this. I have tested the shapes in many positions and configurations, and these are the only ones which work. In fact, you need a very well calibrated 3D printer to get them right, specially the phillips and slotted tips, because they are quite thin. The layer height also have to be at most 0.10mm; higher values won't work. Please CHECK the gcode path before attempting to print! Wrong settings will spoil the print - again, this is a very difficult print. You might want to set XY compensation / horizontal size compensation to a value higher than zero (I have used 0.10mm) if the tip ends do not appear. Bill of materials No extra materials are needed, but you can use the hexagon handle to fit in a common screwdriver handle.

Once you have printed the parts you might have to sand them. Take care, the tips are thin and can break easily. If you need to enlarge an orifice, use a heated metal tip to do it. You might try a trick with the tip if it prints too rough: heat it with a lighter or a heat gun until it is soft (but not melting) and then dip it in the trimpot; hopefully it will conform to its shape.
